Copy editors
on strike
•The

copy editors of the
News-Letter went on strike
last week protesting recent
harsh criticism from both
readers and the editorial
board. They claim that they
have been unfairly accused,
and that the public is just
being too critical. "After all,
we're not prefect!" cried one
editor, protesting outside the
News-Letter Goathouse.
The recent decreale in the
quality of copy editing is
I.lieved to be linked to the
Nose-Letter's recent decision
to drop the abty to read or
write English as a requirement for the staffs' members.
The decline is painfully
dent in the two page errata
section and the errata errata
section, containing corrections to the previous week's
erotica section.
Evidence can be found in
headlines such as, "Lady Laxitives Regulate Swarthmore",
which should have read
"Lady Laxers Rout Swarthmore" or "Bob, Check This
Article for Misspellings."
Editor's Note: We at the
News-Lighter would like to
apologize for all of the nasty
things we've called our copy
editors,
especially
the
remarks about their blatant
stupidity.

"Hi, I'm Stanley Ford,
and this is my University."
Not every man has got what it takes to found his
own University. But I reckon that 20 years selling
used cars gives a man an education that you just
can't buy - until now!

When my NRA buddies come up to me
and say, "Anil, you'll shoot anything!" I
tell 'em, "That just ain't so. I only shoot
deer, but I ain't no Bambi killer. I hunt
John Deere."
"...Yeah, this one almost got away. Usually a good shot between the eyes will drop a
normal deer. But only a well-placed bazooka
shell to bag ya a John Deere. That's why I
carry the Thumper X-25 Assault Bazooka.
It rips through titanium like a plow through
cow patties."

Archeological History Uncovers Rise of
Republicans
SCAGGSVILLE, MD(Apr
19)Recent archaeological digs
in and around Washington
have uncovered two divergent
paths in the evolution of
modern man. Sharing a comhomo
mon ancestor in
erectus, the newly discovered
horno republicu8 species is
considered to be industrious,
intelligent and highly secretive.

10,000 years ago, when
most homo sapiens were still
cave dwellers, homo republicus tribes had erected
established
governments,
armies, coined currency, and,
most importantly, created the
first tax in ancient Ur.
Perhaps the most startling
revelation is that homo
republicus man is still
existent and living among us

today, even after significant
interbreeding.
Homo Republicus men are
distiguished by their:
- shrunken hearts
- larger brains and mouths
- antennae (often well disguised)
- prep school ties
- immovable hair

NEWS-LETTER/5

LettersWhen the Chips are Down

To the Editors:
I finally got her. For weeks
now I have been telling you
of the fiscal abuses by the
Office of the Chaplain and,
most notably, the escapades
of Ms. Gretchen Van Utt.
Now I have solid proof.
Proof, that I humbly suggest
was right under our noses for
some time now.

If you are munching on
potato chips or pretzels or
other such snack food while
reading the News-Letter, you
are not alone. According to
my research, students annually consume 600,000 pounds
of snack food in the Baltimore area alone. Now, look
at the brand name. I found
that our chaplain has been
•

piping thousands of dollars of
school funds into "Utz" brand
snack foods and skimming
profits for personal gain! Six
hundred thousand pounds of
snacks amounts to a lot of
clams for Ms.'Van Utz". Or
should I say clam dip?

Most obviously, the proof
here is in the name. Why
would a company with a
profit motive want to name
itself Utz? It's not that
catchy. Yet our chaplain
thought she could fool Hopkins undergrads with the
slightest change of a letter.
Ha! We shall not put up
with these abuses.
Vehemently, I brought my
case before the Board of
Trustees. That is when I
found how far the corruption
has spread. After presenting
them with the irrefutable evidence, they laughed at me;
that is why I am appealing to

you fellow students. We
must not let the larceny continue! Today its pretzels.
tomorrow it will be busts of
Karl Marx in pinto bean dip!!
We must stop her, for its
more than our money she's
wasting, she's slowly and
surreptitiously tightening the
screws on our minds!! Kill!
Kill! Kill!
Gregory Francis

state of the Black & Blue
Jay. So I thought I'd address
the community and set things
straight.
You couldn't find a nicer,
more diligent group of people
than the BnBJ staff. Despite
a low submission rate, they
do their darndest to get out
some of the best comedy I've
ever read. So next time you
say, 'Where the heck is that
Black & Blue Jay," remember
someone is working hard to
make you smile.
Bruce Herman

Arts
.Zen and the Art of Motor Skills
Nobody Here Gets Out With Motor Skills is the
unedited diary of Skid Viscous, the teenage rock star
who gained notoriety in 1987 by shaving a fully
grown alpaca on stage.
Viscous literally lived his life in the fast lane. A
hyperkinetic since birth, his mind raced from idea to
idea like a Chipmunks album at 78 rpm. As a freshman at Cal Tech, he quickly took to the music scene
despite his studies and was an intensely prolific songwriter.
Motor Skills is a detailed account of his meteoric
rise to fame, his excruciating cheetos addiction, and
the subsequent failure of the band's second album—
all in the span of three week's time. It documents
the new American dream, raw and vulgar, sanctifying the ideals of living fast and high and burning up
on re-entry. The book recreates the disorientation of
hitting escape velocity but firing your retros too late,
keeping zero attitude but losing your tracking radar
communications with ground control, hopelessly
throwing you into a asynchronous orbit. It's tragic.
Viscous kept the diary in his spare time (which was
about every five minutes). Here is an excerpt.
Chapter One: The Early Days
8:00 AM - Wake up. Shower. Brush teeth.
8:27 AM - My roommate Jim tells me that he'd like
to start up a band, and he wants me(!) to play guitar. What a great idea! Except, I tell him I can't
play guitar. I'm not even sure how to hold it. He
says it's no problem since Bono can't play one either,
and he did really well with Cher in the sixties.
8:31 AM - I change my name to Eric Vicious, but my
friends call me "Ric the Vic." If they don't, they're
no friends of mine.

8:33 AM - Pick up my roommate's electric guitar

and give it a strum. Loud.
Discordant. Perfe,t.
9:02 AM - Drop out of school to devote all my time
to the band.
9:03 AM - Realization hits that me and Jim are the
band, so I set out to find a bass guitarist and a drummer (Jim plays keyboards).
9:17 AM - I write my first song: "I Want to French
Your Poodle" for drums, guitar, and chainsaw.
9:20 AM - Jeepers, I never realized my true militant
self until I started this punk group.
9:22 AM - I change my name to Eric
I'llfuckupyourfacewheneverIwant. But my friends
call me 'Tuck up". If anyone calls me "Ric the Vic",
they're no friend of mine.
9:30 AM - Going down to the docks to find some
classy musicians.
10:42 AM - Is this my lucky day or what? I found a
bass player named Sparabuc and a drummer named
Drownzo.
10:51 AM - I've decided to call the band "Rectal
Power Drill" because it seems to fit the mood of our
music. Noon - Here it is, only half the day gone, and
I've alreaxly written twelve songs. We're sure to
make it big. The first hit single we plan to record
is
"If You Think Leather is Exciting Baby,
You've
Never Tried Burlap".
The passion in this book is startling. The images
are ripe and hot and—actually I'm kind of ambivalent
about the whole thing, because I only read this
excerpt and the chapter about Viscous' first experience with cocaine. Can you imagine that? A hyperkinetic on cocaine. The whole chapter is "I'M FLYING!!!!!!!!" 252 times. Geez.

In May of last year, Declan
Aloysius
Bob
McManus,
known to his friends as
veteran new-waver Elvis Costello, finally looked at a photo
of Buddy Holly. For years,
friends had laughed at Costello while singing "American
Pie." The British guitarist
had never seen Holly, and
found the photo by accident.
He was stunned - the two
were indistinguishable,
The ensuing months can
only be described as a rockand-roll dream. Costello flew
to the States and drove to
Holly's parents' house in
Columbia, MD. Mrs. Holly
led Costello up to Buddy's
room, where his then 49year-old lookalike was lying
on his bed and reading a
comic. The two introduced
themselves and quickly hit it
off. Shortly afterwards, Holly
dusted off his guitar. They
wrote some songs and drove
up to New York in Costello's
Aston-Martin to record them.
Then they found Steve Lillywhite, and asked him if
he'd mind producing.
And last week, after months
of guitar riffs and production
mixes, the first Holly-Costello
album, Frosty, is out on the
Sire label. Costello chose the
name in order to distinguish
it from his tough new solo
named Spike. And where
Spike finishes, Frosty begins,
with jumper-cables of guitar

excitement.
Perhaps the most remarkable and pleasing thing about
Frosty is the chemistry Costello shares with Holly. Their
voices are similar in most
places, preventing the need
for 80's-slick-powerpop overdubbing, and where the two
fluctuate slightly, the recordings contain a pleasant warble, such as on 'Blue Sea,"
the first single from the collaboration. In this track, Holly
sings tenor while Costello
strains to sing at soprano,
producing a vocal effort at
once endearing and addictive.
Another key track is the
Latino-Afro-Country
tune,
"Got Boots, Got Dem
Thangs." The guitar work
here is, as always, hooky,
staccatoed, and crispy. Holly
dusts off his pen, dormant for
30 years, to produce some
thoughtful, ponderous lyrics:
'When I saw the flamenco/ I
knew was time to go/ So I
put my boots/ Put my/ Got
my boots dem thangs." The
spiralling snaky guitar from
Costello produces a surreal
world-sound reminiscent of
Bushmen folkchants and Redneck fiddles.
Side one ends with the masterful duet "Time to Find It,"
a veritable tour de force of
sliding hooks and icy vocals
from the two gentlemen.
Comparisons with all great
guitarists from Jerry Garcia

Features
Yes Virginia, There is a Black & Blue Jay
by Hammond Egz
As one of the more inspirational clubs on campus, the
Black & Blue Jay has been
filling the lives of millions
with laughter for five years
now. The group describes
itself as an equal opportunity
offender and publishes articles
about itself when it needs to
fill space the night before a
publishing deadline.
Alumni of the B&BJ can be
found writing for such celebrities as David Letterman,
Gary Shandling, Jay Leno,
and Dan Quayle. But life is
not all fun and games for this
bunch. The group holds
several fundraisers a year to
support their favorite charity,
the Scholarship Fund for
Children of Extraterrestrial
Kidnapping Victims.
The B&BJ encompasses a
wide variety of Hopkins students with many diverse
talents and hobbies. At a
typical meeting you might
find Director of Nepotism,
Tim McDonald, practicing
the ancient art of rap haiku,
master
or
paper
clip
straightner
Joe
McKee
demonstrating his god-given
skills (he can bend them back
to their original shape, too!).
Jay Lechtman enjoys telling
tales of his days as a professional pall bearer, and Bret
Derman is always anxious to
share whatever new inspirational messages he's gotten

from The Weather Channel.
Eric Blumenfeld is always
ready to show off his rapidly
growing
lint
collection.
Alpha Phi alumnus, corporate call girl, and gourmand Kim Pitts stated her
reason for joining the group:
"I need a sense of humor in
my line of work."
The
activities
group's

spread joy throughout the
Charles Village area. Their
fearless leader often leads
expeditions to local laundramats in search of lint,
while Bonnie and Ellen enjoy
nothing more than walking
their pet turtle through the
sculpture garden. And Production Editor Elizabeth
Powell is trying to find out

just how far $.90 and a
transfer can get you on public
transportation (gosh we miss
her).
Through
their
undying
devotion to world peace and
harmony the Black 8 Blue
Jay represents a level of
excellence unrivaled on this
campus and serves as an
inspiration to all.

Pre-Med Thesis Revealed
It is sad commentary that
academia looks down upon
the undergraduate, especially
since much of the nation's
leading research is being done
by them. At Hopkins, two
undergraduate
biology
majors, John Swetman and
Doris Funnel, have made
startling advances in molecular cell biology. What follows

FIGURE

is their final project write-up.
My lab partner and I have
completed our independent
project on the applications of
MOB lab techniques to everyday household subjects. Our
procedure and results are as
follows:
For the initial part of our
experiment we performed
high voltage electrophoresis

on a mouse. First we secured
the mouse and hooked up the
electrodes (fig.1A), then we
turned on the juice and let
him have it (fig. 1B). We're
still trying to interpret our
results (fig.1C).
In the second phase of our
experiment, we performed
the Biuret assay on a stray
cat. We encountered some

difficulty with this experithe
cat
because
ment
scratched my partner when
he tried to stuff it into the
spectrometer.
We
also
couldn't find another cat to
use as a standard. Anyway,
the cat turned blue so I guess
there was protein in it.
For the last part of our
experiment, we centrifuged

our T.A. The results are
shown in fig.2. We haven't
been able to scrape him off
the bottom of the tube yet, so
our conclusions are sketchy at
best. As such, we would like
to try this one again, and are
currently
looking
for
volunteers.

235-1234.

10/APRIL 28s 1989

Sports
This Week in Sports with
Pat Furey
by Patrick "Zeus" Furey
Welcome, sports fans, to
another awesome edition of
what I excelled at during the
week. As always, there are
many exciting and amazing
highlights to "ooh" and "aah"
over.
brilliance
Monday:
My
shone through on Monday as
the last game in last week's
picks was decided. Naturally, I was right, and along
with my other great picks, I
raised my record for the year
to 105%. As you can imagine, this is the most impressive record that anyone has
ever heard of.
Tuesday: On Tuesday, I
singlehandedly trounced both
of my roommates in hall ball
(international rules) by a
score of 10 to 2. The high
point in the action came in
the last few seconds of the
game as I did a ninja-like triple somersault to score the
final goal in the game.
Wednesday:
Wednesday
brought Import Night at
P.J.'s. As usual, I made my
appearance and promptly
challenged everyone to a
game of P.J.'s basketball.
Although several members of
the Hopkins basketball team
were present, I made victory
after stunning victory. The
only challenge came in game
20, when someone came
within twenty-five points of
me, but I recovered and beat
her down.
Thursday: TV night hit
and I set an impressive per-

('I

sonal record of watching
seven hours of television
without going to the bathroom. Yes, fans, there are
still fellows like me around-hardy inside and out.
Friday: Friday found me at
the TEP house, where I was
dynamite at every drinking
game they could throw
against me. I finished the
night in top form by drinking
every one of my opponents
under the table. Only a
select few, like me, can hold
their alcohol against such
odds.
Saturday: My most awesome triumph came on Saturday. I entered the Baltimore
Grand Prix and put myself at
a slight handicap by driving a
Schwinn Roadster 3-speed.
Amazingly, even this did not
keep me down as I beat the
nearest car by 30 minutes.
Sunday: Of course, Sunday
was my day of rest. Being
Zeus allows me one day to sit
back and reflect on my
impact on the sports world.
To relax, I entered every BIA
event, and won.
This concludes my incomparable week in sports. Be
sure to join me again next
week as I make the events of
this week look like baby cake.

Team cheating was introduced as the newest BIA
event last week. The event
was created in an attempt to
fill the void left by the dropping of badminton from the
spring schedule, since all the
birdies were stolen last year.
Students from all departments formed teams and
amazed their professors with
their creative deceptions.
Computer science majors
demonstrated the latest in
parrallel processing and distrubuted cheating. Members
of the Near Eastern Studies
Department choose to use the
time
honored
pyramid
method. While claiming to
be "just stretching," a group
of English majors used semaphore to dictate the entire
second act of Hamlet without
missing a single line. Other
techniques
included
Boltzmann Machines, Recursive structures, and passing
notes to the guy behind you.

dent in the two page errata

To the Editors:
I finally got her. For weeks
now I have been telling you
of the fiscal abuses by the
Office of the Chaplain and,
most notably, the escapades
of Ms. Gretchen Van Utt.
Now I have solid proof.
Proof, that I humbly suggest
was right under our noses for
some time now.

If you are munching on
potato chips or pretzels or
other such snack food while
reading the News-Letter, you
are not alone. According to
my research, students annually consume 600,000 pounds
of snack food in the Baltimore area alone. Now, look
at the brand name. I found
that our chaplain has been
•

piping thousands of dollars of
school funds into "Utz" brand
snack foods and skimming
profits for personal gain! Six
hundred thousand pounds of
snacks amounts to a lot of
clams for Ms.'Van Utz". Or
should I say clam dip?

Most obviously, the proof
here is in the name. Why
would a company with a
profit motive want to name
itself Utz? It's not that
catchy. Yet our chaplain
thought she could fool Hopkins undergrads with the
slightest change of a letter.
Ha! We shall not put up
with these abuses.
Vehemently, I brought my
case before the Board of
Trustees. That is when I
found how far the corruption
has spread. After presenting
them with the irrefutable evidence, they laughed at me;
that is why I am appealing to

you fellow students. We
must not let the larceny continue! Today its pretzels.
tomorrow it will be busts of
Karl Marx in pinto bean dip!!
We must stop her, for its
more than our money she's
wasting, she's slowly and
surreptitiously tightening the
screws on our minds!! Kill!
Kill! Kill!
Gregory Francis

6/APRIL 280 1989

Arts
.Zen and the Art of Motor Skills
Nobody Here Gets Out With Motor Skills is the
unedited diary of Skid Viscous, the teenage rock star
who gained notoriety in 1987 by shaving a fully
grown alpaca on stage.
Viscous literally lived his life in the fast lane. A
hyperkinetic since birth, his mind raced from idea to
idea like a Chipmunks album at 78 rpm. As a freshman at Cal Tech, he quickly took to the music scene
despite his studies and was an intensely prolific songwriter.
Motor Skills is a detailed account of his meteoric
rise to fame, his excruciating cheetos addiction, and
the subsequent failure of the band's second album—
all in the span of three week's time. It documents
the new American dream, raw and vulgar, sanctifying the ideals of living fast and high and burning up
on re-entry. The book recreates the disorientation of
hitting escape velocity but firing your retros too late,
keeping zero attitude but losing your tracking radar
communications with ground control, hopelessly
throwing you into a asynchronous orbit. It's tragic.
Viscous kept the diary in his spare time (which was
about every five minutes). Here is an excerpt.
Chapter One: The Early Days
8:00 AM - Wake up. Shower. Brush teeth.
8:27 AM - My roommate Jim tells me that he'd like
to start up a band, and he wants me(!) to play guitar. What a great idea! Except, I tell him I can't
play guitar. I'm not even sure how to hold it. He
says it's no problem since Bono can't play one either,
and he did really well with Cher in the sixties.
8:31 AM - I change my name to Eric Vicious, but my
friends call me "Ric the Vic." If they don't, they're
no friends of mine.

8:33 AM - Pick up my roommate's electric guitar

and give it a strum. Loud.
Discordant. Perfe,t.
9:02 AM - Drop out of school to devote all my time
to the band.
9:03 AM - Realization hits that me and Jim are the
band, so I set out to find a bass guitarist and a drummer (Jim plays keyboards).
9:17 AM - I write my first song: "I Want to French
Your Poodle" for drums, guitar, and chainsaw.
9:20 AM - Jeepers, I never realized my true militant
self until I started this punk group.
9:22 AM - I change my name to Eric
I'llfuckupyourfacewheneverIwant. But my friends
call me 'Tuck up". If anyone calls me "Ric the Vic",
they're no friend of mine.
9:30 AM - Going down to the docks to find some
classy musicians.
10:42 AM - Is this my lucky day or what? I found a
bass player named Sparabuc and a drummer named
Drownzo.
10:51 AM - I've decided to call the band "Rectal
Power Drill" because it seems to fit the mood of our
music. Noon - Here it is, only half the day gone, and
I've alreaxly written twelve songs. We're sure to
make it big. The first hit single we plan to record
is
"If You Think Leather is Exciting Baby,
You've
Never Tried Burlap".
The passion in this book is startling. The images
are ripe and hot and—actually I'm kind of ambivalent
about the whole thing, because I only read this
excerpt and the chapter about Viscous' first experience with cocaine. Can you imagine that? A hyperkinetic on cocaine. The whole chapter is "I'M FLYING!!!!!!!!" 252 times. Geez.

In May of last year, Declan
Aloysius
Bob
McManus,
known to his friends as
veteran new-waver Elvis Costello, finally looked at a photo
of Buddy Holly. For years,
friends had laughed at Costello while singing "American
Pie." The British guitarist
had never seen Holly, and
found the photo by accident.
He was stunned - the two
were indistinguishable,
The ensuing months can
only be described as a rockand-roll dream. Costello flew
to the States and drove to
Holly's parents' house in
Columbia, MD. Mrs. Holly
led Costello up to Buddy's
room, where his then 49year-old lookalike was lying
on his bed and reading a
comic. The two introduced
themselves and quickly hit it
off. Shortly afterwards, Holly
dusted off his guitar. They
wrote some songs and drove
up to New York in Costello's
Aston-Martin to record them.
Then they found Steve Lillywhite, and asked him if
he'd mind producing.
And last week, after months
of guitar riffs and production
mixes, the first Holly-Costello
album, Frosty, is out on the
Sire label. Costello chose the
name in order to distinguish
it from his tough new solo
named Spike. And where
Spike finishes, Frosty begins,
with jumper-cables of guitar

excitement.
Perhaps the most remarkable and pleasing thing about
Frosty is the chemistry Costello shares with Holly. Their
voices are similar in most
places, preventing the need
for 80's-slick-powerpop overdubbing, and where the two
fluctuate slightly, the recordings contain a pleasant warble, such as on 'Blue Sea,"
the first single from the collaboration. In this track, Holly
sings tenor while Costello
strains to sing at soprano,
producing a vocal effort at
once endearing and addictive.
Another key track is the
Latino-Afro-Country
tune,
"Got Boots, Got Dem
Thangs." The guitar work
here is, as always, hooky,
staccatoed, and crispy. Holly
dusts off his pen, dormant for
30 years, to produce some
thoughtful, ponderous lyrics:
'When I saw the flamenco/ I
knew was time to go/ So I
put my boots/ Put my/ Got
my boots dem thangs." The
spiralling snaky guitar from
Costello produces a surreal
world-sound reminiscent of
Bushmen folkchants and Redneck fiddles.
Side one ends with the masterful duet "Time to Find It,"
a veritable tour de force of
sliding hooks and icy vocals
from the two gentlemen.

guitarists from Jerry Garcia

Features
Yes Virginia, There is a Black & Blue Jay
by Hammond Egz
As one of the more inspirational clubs on campus, the
Black & Blue Jay has been
filling the lives of millions
with laughter for five years
now. The group describes
itself as an equal opportunity
offender and publishes articles
about itself when it needs to
fill space the night before a
publishing deadline.
Alumni of the B&BJ can be
found writing for such celebrities as David Letterman,
Gary Shandling, Jay Leno,
and Dan Quayle. But life is
not all fun and games for this
bunch. The group holds
several fundraisers a year to
support their favorite charity,
the Scholarship Fund for
Children of Extraterrestrial
Kidnapping Victims.
The B&BJ encompasses a
wide variety of Hopkins students with many diverse
talents and hobbies. At a
typical meeting you might
find Director of Nepotism,
Tim McDonald, practicing
the ancient art of rap haiku,
master
or
paper
clip
straightner
Joe
McKee
demonstrating his god-given
skills (he can bend them back
to their original shape, too!).
Jay Lechtman enjoys telling
tales of his days as a professional pall bearer, and Bret
Derman is always anxious to
share whatever new inspirational messages he's gotten

from The Weather Channel.
Eric Blumenfeld is always
ready to show off his rapidly
growing
lint
collection.
Alpha Phi alumnus, corporate call girl, and gourmand Kim Pitts stated her
reason for joining the group:
"I need a sense of humor in
my line of work."
The
activities
group's

spread joy throughout the
Charles Village area. Their
fearless leader often leads
expeditions to local laundramats in search of lint,
while Bonnie and Ellen enjoy
nothing more than walking
their pet turtle through the
sculpture garden. And Production Editor Elizabeth
Powell is trying to find out

just how far $.90 and a
transfer can get you on public
transportation (gosh we miss
her).
Through
their
undying
devotion to world peace and
harmony the Black 8 Blue
Jay represents a level of
excellence unrivaled on this
campus and serves as an
inspiration to all.

I used to have trouble getting my graduate students to
take data, but I found that
bashing them over the head
with empty beer bottles got
them to take plenty of data.
And what's more, they don't
complain about the lifethreatening conditions in the
lab anymore. They even
gave me a gift! It's ticking,
so it must be a clock.
Yours sincerely,
Dr. Bob Rasputin

Great idea! But you need
not confine yourself to beer
bottles. Try coffee cans, pick
axes, and rusty XACTO
knives to vary the effect.
Have a bash!
Hugs,
Heloise

and then you get this dense

ears.
Gross! I always used to use a

the
Q-tip box says you shouldn
't
stick them in your ears, so I
found a great new way. I use
lemon fresh Endust to cut
that waxy buildup, and it
works great.

It is sad commentary that
academia looks down upon
the undergraduate, especially
since much of the nation's

undergraduate
biology
majors, John Swetman and
Doris Funnel, have made
startling advances in molecular cell biology. What follows

FIGURE

is their final project write-up.
My lab partner and I have
completed our independent
project on the applications of
MOB lab techniques to everyday household subjects. Our
procedure and results are as
follows:
For the initial part of our
experiment we performed
high voltage electrophoresis

on a mouse. First we secured
the mouse and hooked up the
electrodes (fig.1A), then we
turned on the juice and let
him have it (fig. 1B). We're
still trying to interpret our
results (fig.1C).
In the second phase of our
experiment, we performed
the Biuret assay on a stray
cat. We encountered some

difficulty with this experithe
cat
because
ment
scratched my partner when
he tried to stuff it into the
spectrometer.
We
also
couldn't find another cat to
use as a standard. Anyway,
the cat turned blue so I guess
there was protein in it.
For the last part of our
experiment, we centrifuged

our T.A. The results are
shown in fig.2. We haven't
been able to scrape him off
the bottom of the tube yet, so
our conclusions are sketchy at
best. As such, we would like
to try this one again, and are
currently
looking
for
volunteers.

10/APRIL 28s 1989

Sports
This Week in Sports with
Pat Furey
by Patrick "Zeus" Furey
Welcome, sports fans, to
another awesome edition of
what I excelled at during the
week. As always, there are
many exciting and amazing
highlights to "ooh" and "aah"
over.
brilliance
Monday:
My
shone through on Monday as
the last game in last week's
picks was decided. Naturally, I was right, and along
with my other great picks, I
raised my record for the year
to 105%. As you can imagine, this is the most impressive record that anyone has
ever heard of.
Tuesday: On Tuesday, I
singlehandedly trounced both
of my roommates in hall ball
(international rules) by a
score of 10 to 2. The high
point in the action came in
the last few seconds of the
game as I did a ninja-like triple somersault to score the
final goal in the game.
Wednesday:
Wednesday
brought Import Night at
P.J.'s. As usual, I made my
appearance and promptly
challenged everyone to a
game of P.J.'s basketball.
Although several members of
the Hopkins basketball team
were present, I made victory
after stunning victory. The
only challenge came in game
20, when someone came
within twenty-five points of
me, but I recovered and beat
her down.
Thursday: TV night hit
and I set an impressive per-

('I

sonal record of watching
seven hours of television
without going to the bathroom. Yes, fans, there are
still fellows like me around-hardy inside and out.
Friday: Friday found me at
the TEP house, where I was
dynamite at every drinking
game they could throw
against me. I finished the
night in top form by drinking
every one of my opponents
under the table. Only a
select few, like me, can hold
their alcohol against such
odds.
Saturday: My most awesome triumph came on Saturday. I entered the Baltimore
Grand Prix and put myself at
a slight handicap by driving a
Schwinn Roadster 3-speed.
Amazingly, even this did not
keep me down as I beat the
nearest car by 30 minutes.
Sunday: Of course, Sunday
was my day of rest. Being
Zeus allows me one day to sit
back and reflect on my
impact on the sports world.
To relax, I entered every BIA
event, and won.
This concludes my incomparable week in sports. Be
sure to join me again next
week as I make the events of
this week look like baby cake.

Team cheating was introduced as the newest BIA
event last week. The event
was created in an attempt to
fill the void left by the dropping of badminton from the
spring schedule, since all the
birdies were stolen last year.
Students from all departments formed teams and
amazed their professors with
their creative deceptions.
Computer science majors
demonstrated the latest in
parrallel processing and distrubuted cheating. Members
of the Near Eastern Studies
Department choose to use the
time
honored
pyramid
method. While claiming to
be "just stretching," a group
of English majors used semaphore to dictate the entire
second act of Hamlet without
missing a single line. Other
techniques
included
Boltzmann Machines, Recursive structures, and passing
notes to the guy behind you.
